text:
Sawaddee Ka, welcome to hot thai kitchen! so 
today i am making noodle meatballs, not noodles

with meatballs, noodles in meatballs yes that's 
a thing in thailand it's a very good thing the

noodles lighten the meatballs they add texture and 
these are so delicious that even my toddler loves

them and trust me that is saying a lot all right 
let's get started so in thai this is called "Moo

Tod Woonsen" moo is pork tod is to fry and woonsen 
is glass noodles yes and as always i'm using pine

brand our sponsor today and i always go with pine 
brand because they're made from 100 pure mung bean

starch as glass noodles should be and so all i'm 
going to do is soak this in room temperature water

and it's only going to take ah this thing doesn't 
pour very well it's only going to take seven

minutes the good thing about glass noodles is 
they don't take long so there's no advanced

planning needed i'm gonna clean my station and 
we'll be right back now we're gonna move on to

making our three friends or sam glow which are 
some white peppercorns garlic and what would have

been cilantro roots but here i'm using cilantro 
stems and i'm just gonna pound this into a paste

that is what you're going for a nice fine paste 
i've got some lean ground pork over here you can

absolutely change this to chicken or even beef 
beef would be good in goes our three friends

goodbye friends and then soy sauce oyster sauce 
some sugar will not taste sweet but you do need

the sugar to balance out the saltiness it will 
make a difference now i'm going to add one egg

which will help tenderize the meatballs keep them 
nice and juicy corn starch which is actually very

important what the cornstarch does it can 
be all-purpose flour any kind of starch

but the starch helps hold on to the juices 
the pork juices so when you go to fry these

the juice stays inside it doesn't leak out into 
the oil which will make your oil last a lot

longer and keep your meatballs juicier and now i'm 
just going to use my hands and knead it together

with hands and gloves is a bad idea 
and now i'm going to use my hands

wrong side and now i'm going to use my hand to 
knead it all together and you really want to

knead make sure everything is mixed well and also 
when you need meat it develops a protein structure

and makes them a little bouncier which in asia 
we like bouncy meatballs okay that looks good
gloves off for now but i want to save it

let's back to the noodles so the noodles are done 
when they're pliable and now i want to make sure i

drain this really well because i don't want excess 
water making the meatballs too soft so you want to

have a towel or something now these need to be cut 
thank you towel to about two inches which might be

longer than you would expect but you don't want 
these to kind of disappear into the meatballs

you want them to you know stick out a little 
bit create a little bit of a texture i might

have done that to shorten certain parts but don't 
worry about it anything that's too long will just

tuck it in into the meatballs along with some 
green onions we use glass noodles in meatballs

because they have a neutral flavor so to go with 
anything and also they're very resilient so you

can knead it and mash it and they're not going 
to you know break apart on you and they're so

versatile because of that now in thailand they're 
also known as the diet friendly noodles because

they're lower in glycemic index and they don't 
raise your blood sugar quite as quickly and also

they absorb a ton of water compared to say rice 
or wheat noodles so in any given servings they're

actually lower in calories so now i'm just kind 
of folding in my gloves not wanting to stay on

folding it because i don't want to 
completely bruise the green onions

that's looking good now this mixture can be made 
in advance keep it in the fridge and then you

fry them up whenever you want if this is your 
first time you might want to take a little bit

cook it up in the microwave or on a skillet to 
check for seasoning just so you can adjust it

to your taste all right let's make some meatballs 
all you have to do is form these into balls about

one and a half to one inch in diameter noodle 
sticking out a bit is okay that'll get crispy but

any long ones you can just pat it down and tuck 
it in if you see any big pieces of green onions

on the surface you can just push that in as well 
so they don't fall off or burn during the frying

but it's not a big deal i like to keep 
the exterior rough but if you want a

smooth look dip your hands in water and that'll 
stop it from sticking and produce a smooth surface

also if you don't want to deep fry you can turn 
these into patties and then shallow fry instead

now i'm going to deep fry these because i actually 
find it easier than individually tending to pan

fried ones this way you can just drop them and 
let them go oil at about 325 to 350 not too hot

and you can just fill the pot i find with this 
as long as there's enough room you don't really

crowd it or anything because if the oil temp 
drops significantly it'll take you longer to

fry but nothing bad will happen to the meatballs 
themselves once they've had like 15 30 seconds

to firm up you can give them a stir and these will 
take about five minutes depending of course on the

size of your meatballs before you ask yes you can 
air fry these but i don't know if they're going to

be as good i've never tried but try it out and 
let us know to check doneness you definitely

want to have a meat thermometer unless you're 
willing to cut one open all right let's take these

out nice so any the black bits are green onions 
that are on the outside it's not a big deal but

that's why you want to tuck them in if you have 
the patience and if you have paper towel oh wow

i did a really good job making those even in size 
and any noodles that are on the surface are gonna

get a little crispy okay one more batch to go look 
at these careful they're very hot give them like

5-10 minutes before you bite in and the way i like 
to serve these is to turn them into a mountain

a mountain of balls it also justifies my uneven 
ball shaping so you put the small one on top okay

good enough now i want to show you first 
the noodles see the noodles on the outside

that is going to add texture and crispiness 
without having to like batter or dip them

and roll them in breadcrumbs or any of that let me 
show you the inside this is the coolest part watch

so cool so cool how fun is that and when you bite 
into it you can hear them so good this is good

on their own but i love it with a sweet chili 
dipping sauce which you can buy or you can make

i have a recipe it's super easy and it's better 
this is one that i have made and i just like to

drizzle and let it right down 
look at that i mean you can still

dip but it just looks so much more appetizing 
when it is glossy and glistening like that

ah man you put that out on a party table 
guaranteed it's going first and i'm gonna

have this one which i already opened because i can 
be sure it's not going to burn a little dippy dip

you can hear the crispiness seriously if you've 
never tried noodles in meatballs glass noodles

specifically this will not work as well with 
other kinds of noodles it's so good that you

get automatic crispiness on the outside because 
the noodles and the exterior will crisp up and

you don't have to mess with panko or anything 
like that and once you bite into it because

there's a lot of noodles inside it actually 
lightens the texture so it's not like just

a big hunk of meat there's nothing wrong with that 
but you know sometimes it's good to have texture

and lightness in the meatballs and you can have 
a lot more of these so i hope you give this a try

the recipe as always will be on HotThaiKitchen.com 
and if you want to watch my videos ad-free and get

bonus content with every episode check out what 
patreon is all about i'll link to that below

thank you as always for watching and i will see 
you next time for your next delicious Thai meal.
